column2: We will lair here tonight, he said, and then with one of his rare, slow smiles: "We will CAMP here tonight."

column3: With an angry toss of his head, the ape man turned upon the two lions who had continued to pace back and forth a few yards from him.

column2: Numa of the lion pit turned a friendly glance in Tarzan's direction, rubbed his head against the ape-man's side, and then directed his snarling countenance toward the two hunters.
column3: Numa of the lion pit turned a friendly glance in Tarzan's direction, rubbed his head against the ape man's side, and then directed his snarling countenance toward the two hunters.

column2: I think, said Tarzan to Numa, "that you and I together can make these beasts very unhappy." column3: I think, said Tarzan to Numa, "that you and I together can make these beasts very unhappy." column3: Come, said Tarzan suddenly and grasping the lion's mane with his left hand he moved toward the other lions, his companion pacing at his side.

column2: As the two advanced the others drew slowly back and, finally separating, moved off to either side.
column3: As the two advanced the others drew slowly back and, finally separating, moved off to either side.

column3: The ape man met the charge of his antagonist after the same fashion of fighting that he had been accustomed to employing in previous encounters with Numa and Sheeta.

column3: To have attempted to meet the full shock of a lion's charge would have been suicidal even for the giant Tarmangani.

column2: With outspread, raking talons and bared fangs Numa sprang for the naked chest of the ape-man.
column3: With outspread, raking talons and bared fangs Numa sprang for the naked chest of the ape man.

column2: Throwing up his left arm as a boxer might ward off a blow, Tarzan struck upward beneath the left forearm of the lion, at the same time rushing in with his shoulder beneath the animal's body and simultaneously drove his blade into the tawny hide behind the shoulder.

column3: With a roar of pain Numa wheeled again, the personification of bestial rage.

column2: Now indeed would he exterminate this presumptuous man-thing who dared even to think that he could thwart the king of beasts in his desires.

column3: But as he wheeled, his intended quarry wheeled with him, brown fingers locked in the heavy mane on the powerful neck and again the blade struck deep into the lion's side.

column2: Easily before had Tarzan locked his legs beneath the belly of a lion while he clung to its long mane and stabbed it until his point reached its heart. So easy it had seemed before that he experienced a sharp feeling of resentment that he was unable to do so now, for the quick movements of the lion prevented him, and presently, to his dismay, as the lion leaped and threw him about, the ape-man realized that he was swinging inevitably beneath those frightful talons.
column3: Easily before had Tarzan locked his legs beneath the belly of a lion while he clung to its long mane and stabbed it until his point reached its heart. column2: With a final effort he threw himself from Numa's back and sought, by his quickness, to elude the frenzied beast for the fraction of an instant that would permit him to regain his feet and meet the animal again upon a more even footing.
column3: With a final effort he threw himself from Numa's back and sought, by his quickness, to elude the frenzied beast for the fraction of an instant that would permit him to regain his feet and meet the animal again upon a more even footing.

column2: But this time Numa was too quick for him and he was but partially up when a great paw struck him on the side of the head and bowled him over.
column3: But this time Numa was too quick for him and he was but partially up when a great paw struck him on the side of the head and bowled him over.

column2: As he fell he saw a black streak shoot above him and another lion close upon his antagonist.
column3: As he fell he saw a black streak shoot above him and another lion close upon his antagonist.

column2: Rolling from beneath the two battling lions Tarzan regained his feet, though he was half dazed and staggering from the impact of the terrible blow he had received.
column3: Rolling from beneath the two battling lions Tarzan regained his feet, though he was half dazed and staggering from the impact of the terrible blow he had received.

column2: Behind him he saw a lifeless lion lying torn and bleeding upon the sand, and before him Numa of the pit was savagely mauling the second lion.
column3: Behind him he saw a lifeless lion lying torn and bleeding upon the sand, and before him Numa of the pit was savagely mauling the second lion.

column2: He of the black coat tremendously outclassed his adversary in point of size and strength as well as in ferocity.
column3: He of the black coat tremendously outclassed his adversary in point of size and strength as well as in ferocity.

column2: The battling beasts made a few feints and passes at each other before the larger succeeded in fastening his fangs in the other's throat, and then, as a cat shakes a mouse, the larger lion shook the lesser, and when his dying foe sought to roll beneath and rake his conqueror with his hind claws, the other met him halfway at his own game, and as the great talons buried themselves in the lower part of the other's chest and then were raked downward with all the terrific strength of the mighty hind legs, the battle was ended.
column3: The battling beasts made a few feints and passes at each other before the larger succeeded in fastening his fangs in the other's throat, and then, as a cat shakes a mouse, the larger lion shook the lesser, and when his dying foe sought to roll beneath and rake his conqueror with his hind claws, the other met him halfway at his own game, and as the great talons buried themselves in the lower part of the other's chest and then were raked downward with all the terrific strength of the mighty hind legs, the battle was ended.

column3: As Numa rose from his second victim and shook himself, Tarzan could not but again note the wondrous proportions and symmetry of the beast.

column2: The lions they had bested were splendid specimens themselves and in their coats Tarzan noted a suggestion of the black which was such a strongly marked characteristic of Numa of the pit.
column3: The lions they had bested were splendid specimens themselves and in their coats Tarzan noted a suggestion of the black which was such a strongly marked characteristic of Numa of the pit.

column2: Their manes were just a trifle darker than an ordinary black-maned lion but the tawny shade on the balance of their coats predominated. column2: The immediate obstruction in his way having been removed, Tarzan was for setting out in search of the spoor of the girl and Smith-Oldwick, that he might discover their fate.
column3: The immediate obstruction in his way having been removed, Tarzan was for setting out in search of the spoor of the girl and Smith Oldwick, that he might discover their fate.

column2: He suddenly found himself tremendously hungry and as he circled about over the sandy bottom searching among the tangled network of innumerable tracks for those of his proteges, there broke from his lips involuntarily the whine of a hungry beast.
column3: He suddenly found himself tremendously hungry and as he circled about over the sandy bottom searching among the tangled network of innumerable tracks for those of his proteges, there broke from his lips involuntarily the whine of a hungry beast.

column2: Immediately Numa of the pit pricked up his ears and, regarding the ape-man steadily for a moment, he answered the call of hunger and started briskly off toward the south, stopping occasionally to see if Tarzan was following.
column3: Immediately Numa of the pit pricked up his ears and, regarding the ape man steadily for a moment, he answered the call of hunger and started briskly off toward the south, stopping occasionally to see if Tarzan was following.

column2: The ape-man realized that the beast was leading him to food, and so he followed and as he followed his keen eyes and sensitive nostrils sought for some indication of the direction taken by the man and the girl.
column3: The ape man realized that the beast was leading him to food, and so he followed and as he followed his keen eyes and sensitive nostrils sought for some indication of the direction taken by the man and the girl.

column2: Presently out of the mass of lion tracks, Tarzan picked up those of many sandaled feet and the scent spoor of the members of the strange race such as had been with the lions the night before, and then faintly he caught the scent spoor of the girl and a little later that of Smith-Oldwick.
column3: Presently out of the mass of lion tracks, Tarzan picked up those of many sandaled feet and the scent spoor of the members of the strange race such as had been with the lions the night before, and then faintly he caught the scent spoor of the girl and a little later that of Smith Oldwick.

column2: Presently the tracks thinned and here those of the girl and the Englishman became well marked.
column3: Presently the tracks thinned and here those of the girl and the Englishman became well marked.

column2: They had been walking side by side and there had been men and lions to the right and left of them, and men and lions in front and behind.
column3: They had been walking side by side and there had been men and lions to the right and left of them, and men and lions in front and behind.

column2: The ape-man was puzzled by the possibilities suggested by the tracks, but in the light of any previous experience he could not explain satisfactorily to himself what his perceptions indicated.
column3: The ape man was puzzled by the possibilities suggested by the tracks, but in the light of any previous experience he could not explain satisfactorily to himself what his perceptions indicated.

column2: There was little change in the formation of the gorge; it still wound its erratic course between precipitous cliffs.
column3: There was little change in the formation of the gorge; it still wound its erratic course between precipitous cliffs.

column2: In places it widened out and again it became very narrow and always deeper the further south they traveled.
column3: In places it widened out and again it became very narrow and always deeper the further south they traveled.

column2: Presently the bottom of the gorge began to slope more rapidly.
column3: Presently the bottom of the gorge began to slope more rapidly.

column2: Here and there were indications of ancient rapids and waterfalls.
column3: Here and there were indications of ancient rapids and waterfalls.

column2: The trail became more difficult but was well marked and showed indications of great antiquity, and, in places, the handiwork of man.
column3: The trail became more difficult but was well marked and showed indications of great antiquity, and, in places, the handiwork of man.

column2: They had proceeded for a half or three-quarters of a mile when, at a turning of the gorge, Tarzan saw before him a narrow valley cut deep into the living rock of the earth's crust, with lofty mountain ranges bounding it upon the south.
column3: They had proceeded for a half or three quarters of a mile when, at a turning of the gorge, Tarzan saw before him a narrow valley cut deep into the living rock of the earth's crust, with lofty mountain ranges bounding it upon the south.

column2: How far it extended east and west he could not see, but apparently it was no more than three or four miles across from north to south.
column3: How far it extended east and west he could not see, but apparently it was no more than three or four miles across from north to south.

column2: That it was a well-watered valley was indicated by the wealth of vegetation that carpeted its floor from the rocky cliffs upon the north to the mountains on the south.
column3: That it was a well watered valley was indicated by the wealth of vegetation that carpeted its floor from the rocky cliffs upon the north to the mountains on the south.

column2: Over the edge of the cliffs from which the ape-man viewed the valley a trail had been hewn that led downward to the base.
column3: Over the edge of the cliffs from which the ape man viewed the valley a trail had been hewn that led downward to the base.

column2: Preceded by the lion Tarzan descended into the valley, which, at this point, was forested with large trees.
column3: Preceded by the lion Tarzan descended into the valley, which, at this point, was forested with large trees.

column2: Before him the trail wound onward toward the center of the valley.
column3: Before him the trail wound onward toward the center of the valley.

column2: Raucous-voiced birds of brilliant plumage screamed among the branches while innumerable monkeys chattered and scolded above him.
column3: Raucous voiced birds of brilliant plumage screamed among the branches while innumerable monkeys chattered and scolded above him.

column2: The forest teemed with life, and yet there was borne in upon the ape-man a sense of unutterable loneliness, a sensation that he never before had felt in his beloved jungles.
column3: The forest teemed with life, and yet there was borne in upon the ape man a sense of unutterable loneliness, a sensation that he never before had felt in his beloved jungles.

column2: There was unreality in everything about him--in the valley itself, lying hidden and forgotten in what was supposed to be an arid waste.
column3: There was unreality in everything about him-in the valley itself, lying hidden and forgotten in what was supposed to be an arid waste.

column2: The birds and the monkeys, while similar in type to many with which he was familiar, were identical with none, nor was the vegetation without its idiosyncrasies.
column3: The birds and the monkeys, while similar in type to many with which he was familiar, were identical with none, nor was the vegetation without its idiosyncrasies.

column2: It was as though he had been suddenly transported to another world and he felt a strange restlessness that might easily have been a premonition of danger.
column3: It was as though he had been suddenly transported to another world and he felt a strange restlessness that might easily have been a premonition of danger.

column2: Fruits were growing among the trees and some of these he saw that Manu, the monkey, ate.
column3: Fruits were growing among the trees and some of these he saw that Manu, the monkey, ate.

column2: Being hungry he swung to the lower branches and, amidst a great chattering of the monkeys, proceeded to eat such of the fruit as he saw the monkeys ate in safety.
column3: Being hungry he swung to the lower branches and, amidst a great chattering of the monkeys, proceeded to eat such of the fruit as he saw the monkeys ate in safety.

column2: When he had partially satisfied his hunger, for meat alone could fully do so, he looked about him for Numa of the pit to discover that the lion had gone.
column3: When he had partially satisfied his hunger, for meat alone could fully do so, he looked about him for Numa of the pit to discover that the lion had gone.
